# Linear Mixed Effects Models 

## Effect of Nitrogen on AMF Families

```{r}
# richness
lmer_gig <- lmer(f__Gigasporaceae ~ site*nitrogen + (1|block:site), data = master_family); anova(lmer_gig); plot(lmer_gig); qqnorm(resid(lmer_gig)); qqline(resid(lmer_gig))
```

## Effect of Nitrogen on Response Variables

```{r lmer_div}
# richness
lmer_rich <- lmer(rich ~ site*nitrogen + (1|block:site), data = master_family); anova(lmer_rich); plot(lmer_rich); qqnorm(resid(lmer_rich)); qqline(resid(lmer_rich))
lsmeans(lmer_rich, pairwise ~ site)
lmer_rich <- lmer(sqrt(rich) ~ site*nitrogen + (1|block:site), data = master_family); anova(lmer_rich); plot(lmer_rich); qqnorm(resid(lmer_rich)); qqline(resid(lmer_rich))
lsmeans(lmer_rich, pairwise ~ site)
ggplot(data = master_family, aes(x = site, y = rich)) + geom_boxplot(aes(fill = nitrogen)) + labs(x = "Site", y = "Family Richness", fill = "N Treatment") + scale_fill_discrete(labels = c("Control", "Amended")) + theme(text = element_text(size = 30)) 
# Shannon's diveristy
lmer_div_shan <- lmer(div_shan ~ site*nitrogen + (1|block:site), data = master_family); anova(lmer_div_shan); plot(lmer_div_shan); qqnorm(resid(lmer_div_shan)); qqline(resid(lmer_div_shan))
# Simpson diversity
lmer_div_simp <- lmer(div_simp ~ site*nitrogen + (1|block:site), data = master_family); anova(lmer_div_simp); plot(lmer_div_simp); qqnorm(resid(lmer_div_simp)); qqline(resid(lmer_div_simp))
# evenness
lmer_even_H <- lmer(even_H ~ site*nitrogen + (1|block:site), data = master_family); anova(lmer_even_H); plot(lmer_even_H); qqnorm(resid(lmer_even_H)); qqline(resid(lmer_even_H))
```

# Indicator Species Analysis

In indicator species analysis, two indicator value components are calculated:

* Component ‘A’ is sample estimate of the probability that the surveyed site belongs to the target site group given the fact that the species has been found. This conditional probability is called the specificity or positive predictive value of the species as indicator of the site group. SO you find this species somewhere, what is the probability that somewhere is part of that group becasue you found it? 
* Component ‘B’ is sample estimate of the probability of finding the species in sites belonging to the site group. This second conditional probability is called the fidelity or sensitivity of the species as indicator of the target site group. SO you are somewhere, what is the probability that you will find that species? 

```{r isa}
# indicators of nitrogen
indval_n <- multipatt(master_family[,34:42], master_family$nitrogen, control = how(nperm = 999))
summary(indval_n)
# indicators of site
indval_site <- multipatt(master_family[,34:42], master_family$site, control = how(nperm = 999))
summary(indval_site, indvalcomp = TRUE)
```

# Ternary Plot

```{r ternary}
df_ternary <- master_family[,c(1, 34:42)] %>% 
  group_by(site) %>%
  summarise_all(~sum(.))
df_ternary <- t(df_ternary)
colnames(df_ternary) <- as.character(unlist(df_ternary[1,]))
df_ternary <- df_ternary[-1,]
df_ternary <- apply(df_ternary, 2, FUN = as.numeric)
df_ternary <- sweep(df_ternary, 1, rowSums(df_ternary), FUN="/")
df_ternary <- df_ternary*100
df_ternary <- as.data.frame(df_ternary)
rownames(df_ternary) <- colnames(master_family[,34:42])
ggtern(data = df_ternary, aes(x=Hancock, y=Oregon, z=Rhinelander)) + geom_point(aes(size = colSums(master_family[,34:42]))) + labs(x = "H", y = "O",z = "R") + geom_crosshair_tern(aes(alpha = colSums(master_family[,34:42]))) + theme(text = element_text(size = 30)) 
```
